#Text=Find Information on Money Market Accounts
#Text=Money market accounts are insured by the government , which makes them safe places where risk-averse individuals can keep extra cash that wo n't lose value when the stock market declines .
#Text=This type of savings vehicle is similar to a savings account , only it usually has a better interest rate for investors .
#Text=In return for a higher interest rate , the account holder must keep a higher average balance and agree to somewhat restricted access to the money .

#Text=To find information on money market accounts , ask representatives at your regular banking institution and compare interest rates online at investment education and banking comparison websites .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Read about money market accounts .
#Text=Look for unbiased financial education at credible websites such as MoneyRates.com 's " Money Market Primer .

#Text=If you are considering making a major purchase and paying with cash sometime during the next year , keep your money  liquid , " which means easily accessible , in a money market account .

column1: #Text=Approach a banking representative at your financial institution .
#Text=Ask to speak to a branch manger , who will usually know more about money market interest rates and investment requirements than a bank teller .
#Text=Describe your savings goals to the bank manager .
#Text=Ask to learn about the money market account with the best interest rates at your bank .
#Text=Ask your banker about account restrictions .
#Text=For example , some money market funds only allow a few transactions a month .
#Text=Some have check-writing privileges , but some do not .
#Text=The more restrictions , the less access you will have to your money when you need it .
#Text=Compare your bank 's interest rates with other financial institutions ' .
#Text=Go online to interest rate comparison websites such as Bankrate.com .
#Text=Click on " Compare Rates .

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text=Choose whether you want an account at a local institution (  Locally available " ) or a national one ( " Highest nationally available " ) .

column1: #Text=The difference between local and national is minimal if online banking is available .
#Text=However local institutions are useful if you want a personal relationship with your account manager .
#Text=Select " MMA " ( Money Market Account ) for a product .

#Text=Sort the selected list of banking institutions according to product ( choose " MMA " ) , annual percentage yield ( how much interest you can earn annually ) and the minimum deposit you will make into the account .
#Text=Review the annual percentage yield ( APY ) interest rates .
#Text=Annual percentage yield ( APY ) is the amount of interest a financial institution pays depositors .
#Text=Calculating APY is done through an algebraic formula with parameters that vary by country .
#Text=Most financial institutions include an online calculator on their websites to help visitors determine APY .
#Text=Compare these APY results against your regular bank 's money market savings account yields , fees and restrictions to find the best interest rate .
#Text=Tips
#Text=Remember that money market accounts are best used as short-term investment vehicles of 1 year or less .

#Text=Although these accounts pay interest , you 'll find higher earnings by placing your money in a Certificate of Deposit ( CD ) account , if you agree to forgo access to your money during a specific time frame .
#Text=Warnings
#Text=When researching money market accounts , utilize financial education websites .
#Text=Avoid conducting research found at investment websites for private companies , since their main goal is to attract customers .
